Many of the remaining outages involve the most extreme and/or remote damage to trees and equipment. We will continue to work to clear fallen trees and branches, and repair equipment damage, ensuring all customers still without power are restored as safely and quickly as possible.

More than 160,000 customers were affected by this weather system and 157,000 have been restored so far; restorations have occurred at a rate of nearly 4,300 per hour since 8 a.m. Sunday. We expect to restore those still impacted before midnight on Tuesday.

As of 9 p.m. on Monday, power has been restored to 98 percent of customers affected by the severe weather system that caused extensive tree damage and brought down more than 1,000 power lines across southeast Michigan Sunday and Monday.

“Sustained high winds caused more than 1,000 downed wires – and many obstacles for our crews in the field – but with your help we were able to identify and clear the vast majority of issues today. Our team will continue to work around the clock as safely and quickly as possible."

“As we work to restore the last of the power outages caused by the high winds that pounded the region yesterday and today, I’d like to thank our customers for their patience and understanding during the restoration process,” said Morgan Elliott-Andahazy, director, DTE Energy.

Safety is always a priority. Stay at least 20 feet away from all power lines and anything they’re in contact with, and consider them live. They are extremely dangerous. Treat every downed power line as if it were energized.

About 17,000 customers are still without power, and we expect to restore the vast majority of them before midnight. We know how difficult it is to be without power, and we thank you for your patience as crews continue to work 16-hour shifts until all safety hazards are cleared.

As of 3:30 p.m. Monday, our crews have restored power to nearly 90 percent of the more than 160,000 customers impacted by the high winds that caused extensive tree damage and brought down more than 1,000 power lines across the region.
Thanks for sharing this, @JermontTerry. Downed power lines are dangerous, even if you are in your car! https://t.co/Qr11afgI5a https://t.co/OTBNSVsV2I

We’ve had more than 1,000 downed wire reports since the wind picked up yesterday morning. Safety is of utmost importance, we ask you to exercise extreme caution when outdoors to watch for downed power lines. For more on safety around downed wires, visit https://t.co/tv7EBE8NBo
We know how difficult it is to be without power, and we ask for our customers’ patience as our crews continue to work 16-hour shifts until all customers are restored.
About 48,000 customers are currently without power. By the end of today, we expect to restore service to 95 percent of customers impacted by the wind storm Sunday and overnight.

As of 10:30 a.m. Monday, our crews have restored power to 70 percent of the more than 160,000 customers impacted by high winds that whipped through the region Sunday and this morning, causing trees and tree branches to take down power lines.

We know how difficult it is to be without power, and we ask for our customers’ patience as our crews continue to work 16-hour shifts until all customers are restored.

By the end of today, DTE expects to have service restored to more than 90 percent of customers impacted by Sunday’s weather, which caused over 500 downed wires. Details on restoration estimates will be available when crews can assess the damage.

As of 5:30 a.m. Monday, DTE crews have restored power to 70 percent of the nearly 155,000 customers impacted by high winds that whipped through the region today, causing trees and tree branches to take down power lines. About 47,000 customers are currently without power.

Because safety is of the utmost importance, we ask that everyone exercise extreme caution when outdoors to avoid coming into contact with a downed power line. We encourage customers to visit https://t.co/JVOX5el20F for tips to identify – and stay safe around – downed power lines.

In any situation, if you smell or suspect a gas leak:
1. Leave the area at once
2. Go to a location where you no longer smell gas, outside of the house or building
3. Call 800-947-5000 immediately to report it
Customer Safety is our #1 priority at DTE. We maintain the safety and integrity of our system of underground natural gas pipes through a robust program of inspections, maintenance and upgrades.

State police and local authorities have taken control of the scene and are investigating. We are supporting the authorities' ongoing investigation into the incident. Again, our immediate thoughts go out to those who were injured today.

In addition DTE has confirmed there was minimal gas consumption at the home prior to midnight yesterday,  as would be expected at a home vacant and for sale. After midnight, however, the house meter measured a higher natural gas spike into the home.

After the incident, DTE's investigators surveyed the area and found no leaks. DTE pressure tested the existing gas lines and found no leaks. Both the main and service lines were confirmed to be operating properly and within specified pressure.

Status update regarding explosion at home for sale in Harper Woods:
 
DTE Energy has conducted additional investigations on the house and area. Our records indicate that there were no leak reports from the neighborhood before the incident.

In any situation, if you smell or suspect a gas leak:
• Leave the area at once
• Go to a location where you no longer smell gas, outside of the house or building
• Call 800-947-5000 immediately to report the situation
Customer Safety is our #1 priority at DTE. We maintain the safety and integrity of our system of underground natural gas pipes through a robust program of inspections, maintenance and upgrades.

Out of an overabundance of caution, we have crews on-site and have measured pressure on the main and it is within our operating guidelines. We have also completed leak testing within the impacted area and and at this time have concluded there are no leaks.

Our heartfelt concern goes out to those who were injured today at the Harper Woods home.

We are supporting the investigation into the incident and until the investigation is complete we will not speculate on the cause.
